Name: Perfluoroheptanoic acid
Description: Perfluoroheptanoic acid is a fluoroalkanoic acid that is perfluorinated heptanoic acid. It has a role as a xenobiotic and an environmental contaminant. It is functionally related to a perfluoroheptane and a heptanoic acid.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Kelly BC et al; Environ Sci Technol 43: 4037-43 (2009)
plant_concentrations.Value: Perfluoroheptanoic acid was detected in two of six macroalgea (Fucus gardneri) samples at <0.01-0.09; samples were collected from the Hudson Bay region of northeastern Canada, during the months of May to Sept between 1999 and 2003(1).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Kannan K et al; Chemosphere 80: 613-18 (2010) (2) Keller JM et al; Environ Sci Technol 39: 9101-8 (2005) (3) Butt CM et al; Environ Sci Technol 41: 3521-8 (2007) (4) Braune BM, Letcher RJ; Environ Sci Technol 47: 616-24 (2013) (5) Falandysz J et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 748-51 (2006) (6) Holmstrom KE, Berger U; Environ Sci Technol 42: 5879-84 (2008) (7) Quinete N et al; Chemosphere 77: 863-9 (2009) (8) Guruge KS et al; Organohalogen Compounds 66: 4029-34 (2004)
animal_concentrations.Value: Perfluoroheptanoic acid was not detected (detection limit 1 ng/g wet weight) in little brown bats (Myotis lucifugus) that had signs of white nose syndrome, collected from caves in eastern New York State from Feb to March 2008(1). Perfluoroheptanoic acid was detected in serum samples from 9 of 73 loggerhead turtles (Caretta caretta) at <100-358 pg/mL and in 1 of 6 Kemp's ridley sea turtles (Lepidochelys kempii) at 101 pg/mL; turtles were caught off the US southeastern coast(2). Perfluoroheptanoic acid was detected at unreported concentrations in northern fulmar (Fulmarus glacialis) from Prince Leopold Island, Nunavut, Canada in samples collected 1993 and 2003(3). Perfluoroheptanoic acid was not detected (detection limit 0.1 ng/g wet weight) in northern fulmar (Fulmarus glacialis) and thick-billed murre (Uria lomvia) eggs sampled 1971-2011 from Prince Leopold Island, Nunavut, Canada; black guillemot (Cepphus grylle), black-legged kittiwake (Rissa tridactyla) and glaucous gull (Larus hyperboreus) eggs sampled in 2008 did not contain perfluoroheptanoic acid(4). Perfluoroheptanoic acid was not detected (detection limit 50 pg/mL) in blood samples from 16 eider duck (Sommateria mollisima), collected from the Gulf of Gdansk in Feb 2003(5). Perfluoroheptanoic acid was not detected (detection limit ng/g) in the muscle (2.2), kidney (1.5), adult liver (4.5), chick liver (4.4) or egg (0.72) of common guillemot (Uria aalge) samples from Stora Karlso Island in the Baltic Sea collected in 1989(6). Tucuxi dolphin (Sotalia guianensis) samples from Paraiba do Sul River, Brazil had perfluoroheptanoic acid concentrations of <0.66, <1.54 and <0.90 ng/g wet weight in liver, muscle and kidney tissue, respectively(7). Perfluoroheptanoic acid was detected at 12 pg/mL or less in blood plasma from three Japanese black beef cattle tracked from 9 to 27 months of age(8).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Keller JM et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 31: 1223-30 (2012)
animal_concentrations.Value: Perfluoroheptanoic acid concentrations were reported in the blood of five sea turtle species collected from Core Sound, NC; Kemp's ridley (Lepidochelys kempii), loggerhead (Caretta caretta), green (Chelonia mydas) and Juno Beach, FL; hawksbill (Eretmochelys imbreicata), leatherback (Dermochelys coriacea); samples were collected June-Oct 2006, June-Aug 2006 and April-May 2007(1).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Kelly BC et al; Environ Sci Technol 43: 4037-43 (2009)

animal_concentrations.Value: Perfluoroheptanoic acid was not detected (detection limit 0.005 ng/g wet weight) in grey seals (Halichoerus grypus) collected from the Baltic Sea from 1969-1985, 1987-1993, 1996, 1998 and 2000-2006(1). Data for years that perfluoroheptanoic acid was detected in seals are summarized below(1).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Tao L et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 7642-8 (2006)
animal_concentrations.Value: Perfluoroheptanoic acid was not detected in the liver of elephant seals (Mirounga leonine), Adelie penguin (Pygoscelis adeliae), South polar skua (Stercorarius maccormicki), black-browed albatross (Thalassarche melanophrys), gray-headed albatross (Thalassarche chrysostoma), light-mantled Sooty albatross (Phoebetria palpebrata), royal albatross (Diomedea epomophora), shy albatross (Thalassarche cauta), wondering albatross (Diomedea exulans), yellow-nosed albatross (Thalassarche chlororhynchos) or Laysan albatross (Diomedea immutabilis); it was also not detected in blood of elephant seal, Adelie penguin, Laysan albatross or South polar skua; and not detected in eggs from Laysan albatross and South polar skua(1).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Wang Y et al; Environ Sci Technol 42: 8146-51 (2008)

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Furdui VI et al Environ Sci Technol 41: 1554-9 (2007) (2) Awad E et al; Environ Sci Technol 45: 8081-9 (2011) (3) Falandysz J et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 748-51 (2006) (4) Holmstrom KE, Berger U; Environ Sci Technol 42: 5879-84 (2008)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Perfluoroheptanoic acid was detected in whole body homogenates of lake trout from lakes Superior, Michigan, Huron, Erie and Ontario at mean concentrations of 0.57, 0.18, 0.42, 0.47 and 0.42 ng/g wet weight, respectively; samples were collected in 2001(1). Perfluoroheptanoic acid was detected in fish samples collected in 2003, 2006 and 2009 from Etobicoke Creek (Toronto, Canada) at <0.2-1.8, <0.2-2.0 and <0.2 ng/g wet weight, and in fish liver samples at <0.2-11.0, 0.2 and 0.3-0.6 ng/g wet weight, respectively(2). Blood samples from 18 cod (Gadus morhua), collected from the Gulf of Gdansk in Feb 2003, contained perfluoroheptanoic acid at <50-740 pg/mL(3). Ten herring, about the size a common guillemot would eat, sampled from Landsort, Baltic Sea in 2005 did not contain perfluoroheptanoic acid (detection limit 1.1 ng/g wet weight)(4).

Perfluoroheptanoic acid was detected at 3 of 5 sites at <1.17-3.97 ng/g wet weight in brown mussels (Perna perna) from Guanabara Bay, Brazil(1). Perfluoroheptanoic acid concentrations in silver scabbardfish (Lepidopus caudatus), whitemouth croaker (Micropogonias furnieri) and mullet (Mugil liza) from Paraiba do Sul River (PS) and Guanavara Bay (GB), Brazil were reported (ng/g wet weight) as follows(1):
fish_seafood_concentrations.Table: [{'Fish': 'Scabbardfish', 'Location': 'PS', 'Number': 10, 'Tissue': 'Liver', 'Concn (ng/g w/w)': '<0.66'}, {'Fish': nan, 'Location': 'GB', 'Number': 12, 'Tissue': 'Liver', 'Concn (ng/g w/w)': '<0.66'}, {'Fish': 'Croaker', 'Location': 'PS', 'Number': 10, 'Tissue': 'Liver', 'Concn (ng/g w/w)': '<0.66'}, {'Fish': nan, 'Location': 'GB', 'Number': 7, 'Tissue': 'Liver', 'Concn (ng/g w/w)': '<0.66'}, {'Fish': 'Mullet', 'Location': 'GB', 'Number': 15, 'Tissue': 'Liver', 'Concn (ng/g w/w)': '<0.66-1.16'}, {'Fish': 'Scabbardfish', 'Location': 'PS', 'Number': 5, 'Tissue': 'Muscle', 'Concn (ng/g w/w)': '<1.54-3.0'}, {'Fish': nan, 'Location': 'GB', 'Number': 4, 'Tissue': 'Muscle', 'Concn (ng/g w/w)': '<1.54'}, {'Fish': 'Croaker', 'Location': 'PS', 'Number': 4, 'Tissue': 'Muscle', 'Concn (ng/g w/w)': '<1.54'}, {'Fish': nan, 'Location': 'GB', 'Number': 4, 'Tissue': 'Muscle', 'Concn (ng/g w/w)': '<1.54'}, {'Fish': 'Mullet', 'Location': 'GB', 'Number': 8, 'Tissue': 'Muscle', 'Concn (ng/g w/w)': '<1.54'}, {'Fish': nan, 'Location': 'GB', 'Number': 17, 'Tissue': 'Kidney', 'Concn (ng/g w/w)': '<0.9-2.03'}]

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Awad E et al; Environ Sci Technol 45: 8081-9 (2011) (2) Stock NL et al; Environ Sci Technol 41: 3529-36 (2007) (3) Pan Y et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 87: 152-7 (2011) (4) Wang T et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 87: 74-9 (2011) (5) Kelly BC et al; Environ Sci Technol 43: 4037-43 (2009)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Perfluoroheptanoic acid was detected in sediment samples collected in 2003, 2006 and 2009 from Etobicoke Creek (Toronto, Canada) at <0.05-0.1, <0.05-0.6 and <0.1 ng/g dry weight, respectively(1). Sediment samples from Resolute, Char and Amituk lakes on Cornwallis Island, Nunavut, Canada contained perfluoroheptanoic acid at <0.18-7.5, <3.3 and <2.9-3.0 ng/g dry weight, respectively(2). Perfluoroheptanoic acid was detected in some of the 23 sediment samples collected Dec 29-30, 2008 from the Haihe River, China(3). Perfluoroheptanoic acid was detected in 1 of 7 sediment samples from the Guanting Reservoir, China at 0.35 ng/g dry weight; samples were collected May of 2008(4). Perfluoroheptanoic acid was not detected (detection limit 0.05 ng/g dry weight) in nine sediment samples collected from the Hudson Bay region of northeastern Canada, during the months of May to Sept between 1999 and 2003(5). SOIL: Perfluoroheptanoic acid was detected in 86 soil samples collected Dec 29-30, 2008 from suburban districts of Tianjin, China at <0.1-0.92 ng/g dry weight(3). Perfluoroheptanoic acid was detected in 2 of 7 soil samples from around the Guanting Reservoir, China at 0.11 and 1.2 ng/g dry weight; samples were collected May of 2008(4).
